comment.author: 21686909@N07
comment._content:
I had forgotten that the Polo Grounds were also known as Brush Stadium, named after John Brush. 

The Polo Grounds had the deepest center field ever in major league baseball.  

Not only did photographers wear ties and hats, so did men in the crowd.  This was standard dress at a ball park all the way up until about 1960.  All of a sudden, men stopped wearing fedoras and straw hats to the park.  At some point in the sixties, guys started wearing ball caps, and stopped wearing ties.

comment.author: 19725722@N06
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called The Photographer Photographed (People who take Photographs), and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 41507621@N05
comment._content: Nikons!  :-)  Nice to have these older photos circulating. I might not have otherwise ever seen it!

comment.author: 99217767@N00
comment._content: Note to all - next time you start whining about how your need a different camera, lens, filter, computer, and/or etc. think of these guys.  They wore suits to the game, focused their cameras manually, figured their own exposers, and could take fewer shots in a minute than you could in a second.  And they still managed to get some amazing photographs.  Imagine what they could do with a modern camera - probably whine that they also need that new 17 - 35 mm zoom...

comment.author: 21686909@N07
comment._content: I forgot to mention above that there were actually THREE different Polo Grounds in NYC over the years!
